review.title: Times series averaging and denoising from a probabilistic perspective on time-elastic kernels
review.abstract: In the light of regularized dynamic time warping kernels, this paper re-considers the concept of time elastic centroid for a setof time series. We derive a new algorithm based on a probabilistic interpretation of kernel alignment matrices. This algorithm expressesthe averaging process in terms of a stochastic alignment automata. It uses an iterative agglomerative heuristic method for averagingthe aligned samples, while also averaging the times of occurrence of the aligned samples. By comparing classification accuracies for45 heterogeneous time series datasets obtained by first nearest centroid/medoid classifiers we show that: i) centroid-basedapproaches significantly outperform medoid-based approaches, ii) for the considered datasets, our algorithm that combines averagingin the sample space and along the time axes, emerges as the most significantly robust model for time-elastic averaging with apromising noise reduction capability. We also demonstrate its benefit in an isolated gesture recognition experiment and its ability tosignificantly reduce the size of training instance sets. Finally we highlight its denoising capability using demonstrative synthetic data:we show that it is possible to retrieve, from few noisy instances, a signal whose components are scattered in a wide spectral band.

sections.heading: 2.3 Discussion and motivation
sections.text: According to the state of the art in time elastic centric estimation, an exact centric, if it exists, can be calculated by solving a NP complete problem whose complexity is exponential with the number of time series averaged. Heuristic methods with increasing time complexity have been proposed since the early 2000s. Simple pairwise progressive aggregation is a less complex approach, but it suffers from its dependence on initial conditions. Iterative aggregation is said to be more efficient, but entails a higher computational effort. It could be combined with ensemble methods or soft optimizations such as genetic algorithms. Non-conveccentric optimization has the merit of addressing the mathematical formulation of the centric problem in a time elastic context. However, this approach involves a higher complexity and has to deal with a relatively large number of parameters that need to be optimized.

sections.heading: 3.5 Role of parameter ν
sections.text: In practice, the selectivity or bandwidth of the local alignment cores (controlled by the parameter ν) must be adjusted according to the lengths of the time series. If the time series are long, ν should be reduced to maintain the predictability of the forward-backward matrices, and the local selectivity decreases. Therefore, more alignment paths are likely and more sample pairs participate in the calculation of the average, so that local details are filtered out by the averaging. Conversely, for short time series ν can be increased, which means fewer sample pairs participate in the calculation of the average and details are preserved.

sections.heading: 4 EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: The first two proposed experiments aim to demonstrate the benefits of using time-elastic centroids in a data reduction paradigm: 1-NC / NM classification (the first near centroid or medoid) for the first and isolated gesture detection for the second using 1-NC / NM and SVM classifiers in conjunction with the KDTW kernel. The third experiment investigates the angle of noise reduction caused by time-elastic centroids.

sections.heading: 4.1 1-Nearest Centroid/Medoid classification
sections.text: The purpose of this experiment is to assess the effectiveness of the proposed temporal averaging method (TEKA) using a triple baseline; the first baseline allows us to compare centrifugal data with medoid-based approaches; the second and third baseline are provided by the DBA [19] and CTW [20] algorithms (thanks to the implementation proposed by the authors), which are currently considered state of the art to highlight the effects of the selected sequences in accordance with DTW. To this end, we have used CTW averaging with a 1-NC-DTW (CTW1) and a 1-NC-KDTW (CTW2) classifier to highlight the effects of the selected similarity measurements. To this end, we empirically evaluate the effectiveness of the methods we compare with a first nearest centrifugal / medoid (1-NC / NM) classification task.

sections.heading: 4.4 Discussion
sections.text: We believe that TEKA's noise filtering capability is mainly due to the averaging technique described in Equation (16), which summarizes many plausible similarities between samples (rather than a best one) while also calculating the timing of the occurrence of samples, especially those that correspond to the expected location and duration of the patterns, such as the CBF shapes or the tip positions in the third experiment. This capability probably also explains the best accuracy results obtained by TEKA compared to the prior art, CTW and DBA. Furthermore, the KDTW measurement appears to be better adapted to centrifuges than DTW. Again, the handling of several good to best alignments, rather than a single optimal one, enables a conformity of centrifuges in many respects averaged by the measurement. This has been verified for CTW in 1-NC classification tasks and applies to TEKA and DBA measurements.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we have addressed the problem of averaging a series of time series in the context of time elastic distance measurement such as dynamic time warping, and the new perspective offered by the kernization of elastic distance allows a reinterpretation of pairwise grain alignment matrices as the result of a forward-backward method applied to the states of equivalent stochastic alignment automates.From this reinterpretation, we have proposed a new algorithm, TEKA, based on an iterative agglomerative heuristic method that enables efficient calculation of good solutions for multiple alignment of time series.This algorithm exhibits quite interesting denoizing capabilities that encompass the scope of its potential application.We have presented extensive experiments based on synthetic and real datasets that included univariate but also multivariate time series.Our results show that centered methods based on meid-linking methods are significantly better in the context of a TEKA at the first and second contextual TEKA at the next level.

metadata.abstractText: In the light of regularized dynamic time warping kernels, this paper re-considers the concept of time elastic centroid for a set of time series. We derive a new algorithm based on a probabilistic interpretation of kernel alignment matrices. This algorithm expresses the averaging process in terms of a stochastic alignment automata. It uses an iterative agglomerative heuristic method for averaging the aligned samples, while also averaging the times of occurrence of the aligned samples. By comparing classification accuracies for 45 heterogeneous time series datasets obtained by first nearest centroid/medoid classifiers we show that: i) centroid-based approaches significantly outperform medoid-based approaches, ii) for the considered datasets, our algorithm that combines averaging in the sample space and along the time axes, emerges as the most significantly robust model for time-elastic averaging with a promising noise reduction capability. We also demonstrate its benefit in an isolated gesture recognition experiment and its ability to significantly reduce the size of training instance sets. Finally we highlight its denoising capability using demonstrative synthetic data: we show that it is possible to retrieve, from few noisy instances, a signal whose components are scattered in a wide spectral band.
